newsitem.title: USA: IGG says in vitro results "promising".
newsitem.headline: IGG says in vitro results "promising".

text.p: An independent evaluation of IGG International Inc's lead carbohydrate-based anti-fungal compound CAN-296 found the product to be very promising, IGG said Monday.
It said Jack Sobel, chief of infectious disease at Harper Hospital and professor of medicine at Wayne State University School of Medicine, had described CAN-296 as a compound with enormous potential.

"The in vitro activity of CAN-296 is remarkable," it quoted Sobel as saying in a presentation to the annual general meeting of the American Society for Microbiology. "In these experiments, CAN-296 showed rapid and potent cidal activity against a broad spectrum of fungal species.
"CAN-296 is different because it is fungicidal, kills the fungus, verses most anti-fungal products that only inhibit the growth of fungus, or fungistatic."
Sobel, who led the independent evaluation, added, "Based on these preliminary results, I believe the clinical potential of CAN-296 is enormous."
The company, which has a patent pending on the compound, said it plans to develop it for both topical and systemic anti-fungal applications.
CAN-296 is a natural complex carbohydrate that has been extracted from the cell wall of certain fungi.
